ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Amazing! I've heard critique that Deb's class does not teach "technique", but that is only on the surface. You will grow as a writer, an actor, and a person, and you will NOT regret having taken this class.
I would recommend this class. It teaches you more about yourself than "Acting", but I think that that is far more important in the long run.

I would recommend THST 210 to another student. It is a prerequisite for the Theater Studies Major, however, it is far more enjoyable and interactive than THST 110& 111. The course is not a course in acting. It is a course in performance. Your experience in the course depends on your professor. The key is selecting the professor who will challenge you and help you to grow as a performer and as an artist.

Yes yes yes! If you can take 210 with Deb, do so. I switched into this section and am so glad that I did. This class turned me on to the world, my own creativity, and the wealth of resources available in creating performance. While traditional scene study is not a large component of the class, I urge you to try something non-conventional and take this. Establishing a practice of writing everyday and creating my own performance pieces was one of the most satisfying aspects of my semester. Without a doubt.

Would absolutely recommend this course! I canât possibly speak more highly about it. This is a class I will always remember. Iâve learned and grown an incredible amount, had so much fun, and really had a chance to get to know everyone in a deeper way than in any other class Iâve taken - 210 fosters a really amazing sense of community. Deb is the greatest â kind, supportive, generous, fun, brilliant, inspiring, and has the most incredible sense of humor. And weâve accomplished so much throughout the semester - It was exciting and rewarding to see the culmination of everyoneâs work in the final performances. I miss our class already. The BEST course Iâve taken at Yale.
I would recommend this class only to prospective theater majors, and those with limited performance background eager to learn more.

Acting 210 is one of the central parts of the Theater Studies curriculum, and it's wonderful. You're going to learn something completely different depending on which instructor you get, but no matter who it is the course is worthwhile and inspiring.

I loved this class so, so much-- I could have gone to it every day. Lots of fun and interesting exercises, and you learn and bond so much as a class. Professor Margolin's class has a lot of writing exercises, and the semester ends with a self-scripted 10-minute performance project, which is so, so rewarding. It's also just wonderful to do scene work in class and get feedback. 210 makes 110 and 111 absolutely worth it. Such an excellent time.
TAKE THIS CLASS!! You will absolutely 100 percent not regret it.
